intro: Matthiola graminea, commonly known as the common wallflower, is a flowering plant belonging to the Brassicaceae family. It is characterized by its compact growth habit and clusters of small, fragrant flowers that range in color from white to pink and purple. The plant typically grows to a height of 15–30 cm and is native to Europe and parts of Asia. Its leaves are lance-shaped and covered in fine hairs, while its stems are often hairy as well. Matthiola graminea is often cultivated in gardens for its ornamental value and ability to attract pollinators.
